content.description:
This route climbs through 4 different sections and feels like 4 different short climbs. The first section is about 5.7 and squeezes thru a fun groove where you gain the first of three ledges. Move to the right.

A small nut works at the bottom of a bulge that you can pull straight over, or move to the right use a left facing crack and wall for a few moves and then back left to stand above the bulge. This feels about like 5.8, and should definitely wake you up. Another ledge with another bulge.

This and the upper section are what you came here for!

A couple of sweet hand jams gets you above this bulge to more easy climbing up to another ledge. This feels like an 8 or a 9.

Follow a right facing flake to a rest below the final crux bulge. Plug in a great cam and a pull the roof with high feet and large side pulls. The final 20 feet is killer hand jamming, but quite pumpy climbing that could send you for a ride with tears in your eyes as your looking up at the oh-so-close anchors.

Watch the end of your 70 meter rope, you should still have about 10 feet left when you get back down.
content.protection: A set of nuts. A set of cams with doubles from 1.5" to 3".
content.location: This starts about 1/3 of the way down The Sheep Wall from the left end. See topo.

content.description:
An easy yet adventurous climb,

Y2K Crackdown

attacks an interesting line across four layers of rock.  Each stratum is a little different, varying rock quality and features, each requiring a different set of techniques to ascend.  Between layers, there are ample resting opportunities on ledge systems that collect rotten rock from above.  It can be easy to run out your protection in these spots, so be careful not to slip on the loose debris.  Chimneying and stemming are frequently used techniques, and jugs appear just as you think the climbing is getting tougher than the rating.  A quick approach makes this a worthwhile warm up.  This route is in the shade in the early afternoon; however, the belay up top is exposed.
content.protection: Medium to large camming devices, helmets and long runners to alleviate rope drag as the route wanders between strata.  Belay from the two-bolt anchor of the neighboring sport route.  Walk off to the north end of the cliff band and down a grassy gully.
content.location: About 40 meters to the north of the end of the cliff band, find a faint, left-facing dihedral.  Above the dihedral is a deep groove that makes a large letter V in the horizon line.  A bolted line resides just to the south of the route.

content.description: Face climb this slabby route with very thin holds and balancy moves. Use the occasional small mono to balance. You can meander right (start) and left (higher up) to make this climb easier. Go straight if you can!
content.protection: 4 or 5 bolts to a pair of bolts on a comfortable ledge at the top. There was pair of long rusted draws for lowering.
content.location: 40 feet to the left of Shetland Dreams

content.description: Climb up the fun finger/handcrack to a short step and belay to avoid rope drag. The second pitch involves some odd pulls through an initial handcrack to a right facing dihedral with a finger crack and fantastic stemming. Make the final awkward moves to the top and enjoy the view.
content.protection: A single set of cams and nuts is sufficient for the route. One bolt on each pitch plus fixed anchors at the first pitchlet and the top. Should be able to rap off with a 70m rope or walk off to the north.
content.location: Look for a single bolt next to a finger crack about 15 feet up. About 100 feet north of Y2K breakdown.

content.description: A bouldery route in the middle of the wall, this climb starts out strong with a crank over a roof. Easier terrain leads to another couple cruxy moves with some ledgey terrain mixed in.
content.protection: About 4 bolts on the route. Supplement with cams and nuts. Chain anchor at the top.
content.location: About halfway between Shetland Dreams on the right and Y2K Crackdown on the left. Look for the two bolts leading up over the bulgy roof and the leaning lieback crack.

content.description: Easy face climbing to a bolt about 15 feet off the deck quickly turns to a puzzling sequence to the next bolt.  Dont traverse too far to the right or left or youll miss the climb altogether.  Once past the second bolt, scramble up to a third bolt and cross some questionable rock on your way to the anchors.
content.protection: 3 bolts to an anchor underneath the roof.  Helmets are recommended due to the rotten rock surrounding the anchors.  Rappel off with a single rope.
content.location: Approximately 40 meters from the north end of the cliff band, a large roof caps a relatively blank face.  Two bolts are easily visible from belay ledge under the roof.

climbs.name: Immediately right of Shetland (still to be named)

content.description: Start on a side pull or hand crack before moving to the right to the face and up to anchors on a comfortable ledge. The crux is the face climbing.
content.protection: Well protected, 4 or 5 bolts to chains.
content.location: This is immediately to the right of Shetland Dreams.
